Dear Pamela Cornell-Allen:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 552-3662.
Sincerely,
Deborah Will, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Public Act MCL 722.111 Definitions:
116 of 1973, (x) “Minor child” means any of the following:
as amended. (iii) A person who is a resident in a child caring institution,
Effective children’s camp, foster family home, or foster family group home;
3/28/18 who becomes 18 years of age while residing in a child caring
institution, children’s camp, foster family home, or foster family
group home; and who continues residing in a child caring
institution, children’s camp, foster family home, or foster family
group home to receive care, maintenance, training, and
supervision. A minor child under this subparagraph does not
include a person 18 years of age or older who is placed in a child
caring institution, foster family home, or foster family group home
under an adjudication under section 2(a) of chapter XIIA of the
probate code of 1939, 1939 PA 288, MCL 712A.2, or under
section 1 of chapter IX of the code of criminal procedure, 1927 PA
175, MCL 769.1.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Minors from the CCI mix with adults in another program on-site.
Investigation Ozone House is the parent agency for a non-MDHHS homeless
shelter serving youths and adults located in a multi-level
residential building in Ypsilanti, Michigan. The licensed child
caring institution on the second and third floors are part of Ozone
House Youth Shelter referred to as Transitional Living and
Safestay respectively. The main floor is a homeless shelter for
adults.
On 5/16/23, I interviewed two anonymous Complainants together
via telephone. They expressed a concern that Youth I, age 17-
years 11-months, is “mixing” with adults who reside in another
program on the main floor.
I arrived at the facility unannounced on 5/17/23 at 10:40am. and
found Youth I sitting in the child caring institution with Staff 1. I
interviewed Youth I. She denied “mixing” with the adult residents
on the lower level. However, on 5/21/23 she said she turns 18
and will be transferring into the adult program.
I interviewed Youth D. She denied she or other minors ever “mix”
with the adult residents adding, “We can’t even say ‘hi’ to them
outside.”
2

I interviewed Staff 1. She was working with the youth today, but
said she usually works with the adults. Staff 1 said the minor
residents are not allowed to mix with the adults.
I interviewed Director. She explained that youths over age 17-
years, 6-months old sleep in Safestay but do participate in adult
programming daily from 3 – 11pm. Director said the organization
has not experienced any negative outcomes as result of the partial
mixed programming for teens nearing adulthood.
Analysis Youths over age 17 years 6 months sleep in the program for
minors and participate in partial day programming with adults from
3 - 11pm. Nothing in Public Act 116 or the Child Caring Licensing
Rules prohibits this.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & Rule 400.4123 Education
Section (2) Provision shall be made for an appropriate education program
Description in accordance with 1976 PA 451, MCL 380.1 to 380.1853. Each
resident of school age shall be enrolled not later than 5 school
days after admission and continuously thereafter.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation A youth was not enrolled in school within five days of placement at
the facility.
Investigation The Complainants reported Youth D is not enrolled in school.
Records indicate Youth D entered the facility on 4/20/23. On
Wednesday 5/16/23 at 10:50am I found her in her room. I
interviewed Youth D. She said she is not enrolled in school
because the high school she last attended in Ohio does not offer
virtual learning. “Case manager is trying to figure out something.
I don’t think they wanted me to go (to school) since I won’t be here
that long.”
I reviewed progress notes by Case Manager pertaining to Youth
D’s education. A note dated 4/21/23 indicates options for
schooling were discussed. Youth plans to go to Job Corps in
June but is open to enrolling in school if she stays (at Safestay) for
an extended period of time. A note dated 4/28/23 indicates Youth
D is not sure about school and is considering enrolling in Ypsilanti
3

High School. On 5/9/23 a note indicated the potential of getting
youth into WAVE school was discussed. Youth requested to
attend Ypsilanti High School and was told it is not an option.
Youth expressed being very eager to get into school.
I interviewed Case Manager via phone on 5/18/23 who shared a
verbal update regarding Youth D’s education. Initially she said
Youth D’s mother was a barrier to her school enrollment.
However, since then, the mother gave Case Manager and Ozone
House permission to enroll her. Online options were explored, but
the programs were not accepting enrollments this late in the
school year. Case Manager said Youth D is currently on a waiting
list for WAVE school and that she and Youth D are meeting with
ACE school on 5/19/23 to explore enrollment possibilities there.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
If youth cannot be enrolled in school within 5 days of placement,
all failed efforts to enroll her should be documented in the youth’s
file.
Analysis Documentation shows failed efforts to enroll Youth D, but schools
were not accepting new enrollments as it was too late in the
school year.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(d) Storage of medications.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Medication is stored haphazardly. Medication from discharged
youths and expired over-the-counter medication has not been
disposed of.
Investigation Complainants alleged that medication is stored in a disorganized
manner. There is medication leftover from previous residents and
some expired medication remains in the cabinet.
I observed the medication cabinet to be locked. Staff 1 unlocked
the cabinet. Prescribed medication is stored on the right side of
the cabinet. Each youth has their own plastic bin. There was no
4

medication leftover from discharged residents and none of the
prescription medication was expired.
I observed the over-the-counter medication stored on the left side
of the cabinet. Most of it was expired. I recommended Director
promptly remove the expired medication. On 5/18/23, Director
reported that all expired medication was disposed of and would be
replaced with new medication.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
Stored over the counter medication should be checked monthly for
expiration dates and all expired medication should be promptly
disposed of.
Analysis Prescription medication was stored in an organized manner in
separate plastic bins for each youth. There was no medication
leftover from previous residents. While it is best practice to do so,
there is no licensing rule requiring immediate disposal of over-the-
counter medication.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(e) Dispensing medication.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Dispensed medication is not always documented appropriately.
Staff are not uniformly trained in medication dispensing and
documentation.
Investigation Complainants alleged that dispensed medication is not always
documented appropriately and not all staff are trained in
medication dispensing or documentation.
I reviewed the April and May 2023 medication logs. Youth D has
a topical cream that is prescribed “as needed,” which she has not
used/needed since April. Youths M and H have prescribed
medications that were dispensed in May 2023. The top portion of
the medication administration records (MARs) were not fully filled
out. There were empty spaces on Youth H’s MAR on May 7 & 8
5

suggesting either the medication was not dispensed, staff
dispensed it and failed to initial the box, or the youth refused it.
I reviewed staff training logs. All 17 training logs showed that
some form of initial medication training and annual refresher
trainings were completed. The annual refresher trainings are only
20 – 30 minutes in duration.
I asked Medication Trainer via email if staff are specifically trained
on how to start a MAR. She confirmed that that is included in their
training.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
Although Medication Trainer said the staff are trained how to fill
out the top portion of monthly MARs, at least one MAR was not
filled out thoroughly. This leads to confusion for the medication
dispenser and for the supervisor monitoring accuracy of MARs. I
recommend that only supervisors or persons who clearly
demonstrate an ability to fill them out thoroughly and correctly be
assigned to start each youth’s MAR upon admission and monthly
thereafter by filling out the top portion.
To prevent medication errors, supervisors or lead staff should
check MARs before the end of the day and afternoon shifts to
assure all prescribed medications were dispensed and properly
documented.
The agency’s annual medication refresher training is brief and
may require more than 20 – 30 minutes.
Analysis At least one MAR was not filled out thoroughly or correctly. Two
medication documentation errors were found on Youth H's MAR
for May 2023.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & Rule 400.4152 Initial documentation
Section (1) At the time of admission, all of the following shall be in the
Description resident’s case record:
(a) Name, address, birth date, gender, race, height, weight, hair
color, eye color, identifying marks, religious preference, and
school status.
(b) A photograph taken within the previous 12 months.
6

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Necessary identifying information of youths is not always readily
available to direct care staff on each shift as needed.
Investigation Complainants expressed concern that necessary identifying
information of youths is not always readily available to direct care
staff on nights and weekends.
The facility chooses to keep two different case files for youth. One
“hard” file that is locked in the case managers’ offices and another
“soft” file for use by the direct care staff. The “soft” file is a subset
of the “hard” file. It is the case managers’ responsibility to copy
certain documents and provide them to direct care staff, who in
turn, assemble the “soft” files. I reviewed the “soft” files of Youths
I, D, H and M. Youths H and M did not have face sheets
(identifying data) and photos necessary for direct care staff to
have in the event of an AWOL or emergency. Youths I and D had
identifying data but were also missing photos.
CONSULTATION
I recommend there only be one case file that all staff have access
to 24/7.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
If the agency chooses to keep dual files, the supervisor of case
managers needs to check behind them to assure all necessary
documents were provided to direct care staff to create the soft file.
Direct care staff should have access to the face sheet, a recent
photo of the youth, consent to treatment forms, safety plans,
insurance cards, emergency contacts and other documents.
Analysis (a) Two of four youth files were missing face sheets containing
identifying data.
(b) Four of four files were missing a photograph taken within the
previous 12 months.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
Interim Inspection 10/14/2021 with approved CAP (sub-rule a)
7

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
